awd_abstract_narration:
Random matrix theory grew out of fundamental considerations in mathematical statistics and theoretical physics, and now has applications in such disparate areas as number theory, statistical mechanics, wireless communications and bioinformatics. A perfect example of the field's reach is offered by the so-called Tracy-Widom laws. First discovered in the description of the largest eigenvalues for certain large random matrices, these laws are now understood to serve the role of the "bell curve" (or provide the appropriate central limit theorem) for a wide area of modern nonlinear phenomena. The main objective of this research is to advance our understanding of these and other probability laws introduced through the study of random matrices. The focus is on their basic mathematical properties, as well as extending the class of models in which they apply.

The research builds in part on the PI's recent work on the general beta extensions of the Tracy-Widom and related distributions. These extensions have the advantage of embedding the more familiar triple(s) of limit laws (tied to the orthogonal, unitary and symplectic symmetry classes) into a one-parameter family of distributions defined via random differential operators. The main goal here is to push this approach toward descriptions of more exotic limit theorems, such as the higher order Tracy-Widom laws and various double scaling regimes (again in the general beta context). Additional projects center around a recently established matrix version of the classical Dufresne identity for integrated geometric Brownian motion as well as solvable matrix models which interpolate between the Gaussian Orthogonal and Symplectic Ensembles and can be viewed as multi-type coulomb gases.

por.por_cntn:
This project centered on random matrix theory, and in particular on the limit laws (or distributions) for various local eigenvalue statistics. These random matrix eigenvalue distributions are now understood to capture a wide array of nonlinear phenomena across various areas of mathematics - this general class of phenomena is now typically referred to as the "KPZ Universality Class". As such, a deeper understanding of these objects is of basic importance.

The approach taken throughout this study, the so-called random operator approach, is relatively new within random matrix theory. Here the distributions in question are characterized via a random, but simple, differential equation. Separate asymptotic eigenvalue regimes are connected to separate random differential equations, with now each of the fundamental regimes having a known random differential equation description. Further, more classical approaches to random matrix theory are tied to the underlying symmetry classes of the matrix ensembles: real symmetric, complex Hermitian, or self-dual quaternion. On the other hand, the the random operator  approach applies to an entire one-parameter family of ensembles for which the three previously understood cases are instances. It also even provides novel characterizations in those cases.

The main goal here has been to advance the random operator approach beyond the aforementioned fundamental limiting eigenvalue regimes.  There exist numerous problems in random matrix theory where the limit is in double-scaling. In these settings the resulting distributions represent some mixture of, or crossover between, those of the fundamental regimes. The relevant analysis is highly technical, and the known results thus far in this direction all pertain to the complex Hermitian symmetry class.  Again, the random operator approach can, in principle, handle all symmetry classes simultaneously, and more.

The project's results have led to random differential equation descriptions in three concrete models which exhibit a double scaling. One model characterizes where two types of eigenvalue edge laws coalesce. The second surrounds the case when a vanishing occurs in the eigenvalue bulk. The last describes generalizations of what are known as the higher-order Tracy-Widom laws. (The classical Tracy-Widom laws themselves being intimately tied to the KPZ Universality Class mentioned above.) The new random differential equations, at least in some instances, can be built out of those characterizing the fundamental regimes. This is as one would have hoped of the theory. 

Throughout the project dedicated funds have been used to support the research travel of both graduate students and postdoctoral fellows members of the Mathematics Department at Temple University. Similarly, several collaborative research visitors to the department were funded by the project.
